data.sampled:
Your income tax if your internship will pay you $75,000 will be:

A. 14,383 B. 16,393 C. 18,282 D. 23,001

Explanation:

Your income tax rate is 20% for 2020 taxes.

Your internship will pay $75,000 which is $37,500 before taxes.

Taxes will only be applied to the amount over the tax threshold which in this case is $33,750 which is $17,500 plus the taxes that are already applied to the amount of $16,375 (16,375 = $33,750 - $17,500).

Your income tax rate for the amount over the tax threshold is 20% * $17,500 / $33,750 = 14.383%

Your total income tax will be:

14.383% * $37,500 = $56,781


Option A: 14,383

Therefore, option A would be your correct answer.

data.sampled:
Your gross income for the summer internship in San Francisco will be $100,000.

The tax rate for 2021 is 21% for individuals and couples.

The taxable income is calculated by multiplying your gross income by the appropriate tax rate. In this case, $100,000 * 0.21 = $24,383.

The federal income tax is calculated by subtracting any tax benefit from itemizing deductions from taxable income. In this case, $24,383 - $4, disproportionately benefits New York state, so your New York state income tax is $22,741.

Your New York state tax liability is calculated by multiplying your taxable income by the appropriate tax rate for New York state. In this case, $22,741 * 0.22 = $5,574.

Your federal tax liability is $24,383 - $22,741 = $2,962.

Your total tax liability for the summer internship in San Francisco is $2,962 + $22,741 = $38,001.

If you live in New York City and you are a college student at MIT, in Cambridge MA, but you live in New York City and you are working as a summer intern in San Francisco which will be your only form of income this upcoming summer, assuming the tax rate is the same as 2021, and your internship will pay you $50,000, your income taxes will be as follows:

Option A: Your taxable income for the summer is $50,000. Your federal income tax rate is 39.6%, which is the highest federal income tax rate for 2020 (and it will stay at that rate in 2021). So, your federal income tax liability for the summer is $19,196 (based on the applicable marginal tax rate of 39.6%).

Option B: Your taxable income for the summer is $50,000. Your federal income tax rate is 25%, which is the lowest federal income tax rate for 2020 (and it will stay at that rate in 2021). So, your federal income tax liability for the summer is $9,098 (based on the applicable marginal tax rate of 25%).

Option C: Your taxable income for the summer is $50,000. Your federal income tax rate is 14.2%, which is the average federal income tax rate for 2020 (and it will stay at that rate in 2021). So, your federal income tax liability for the summer is $26,140 (based on the applicable marginal tax rate of 14.2%).

Option D: Your taxable income for the summer is $50,000. Your federal income tax rate is zero, which is the lowest federal income tax rate for 2020 (and it will stay at that rate in 2021). So, your federal income tax liability for the summer is $0 (based on the applicable marginal tax rate of zero).

So, as a college student at MIT, in Cambridge MA, but living in New York City and working as a summer intern in San Francisco, your federal income taxes will be as follows: Option C: $26,140 + State income taxes (if applicable) = $31,840.
